thread.title: Council's meeting over free public Wi-Fi somehow turns into row over Brexit

author: Daniel Clark
title: Council's meeting over free public Wi-Fi somehow turns into row over Brexit
text:
Flowers outside shop where man died
But Cllr Alistair Dewhirst said: “Brexit is the biggest thing to happen to the country since the Second World War, so to leave it off the list is burying our heads in the sand.
“Farmers in my ward are terrified to moving onto WTO tariffs and are terrified as to what the French will do with our food. There is only one topic being discussion at the moment and we are just going to ignore it.”
Cllr Gordon Hook added: “I know that some Devon farmers are struggling to get food out of the fields as Brits are not doing the work and EU nationals are returning home. We ought to be concerned about that threat to our agricultural industry.”
Watch: Brexit 'a real opportunity' Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
But Cllr Humphrey Clemens, himself a farmer, said: “There are very few farms in Teignbridge where mass numbers of workers for fruit and vegetable picking are required. I don’t hear farmers crying out for farm workers to milk the cows or sheer the sheep.”
Cllr Jeremy Christophers, leader of the council, said that he was happy for people to debate Brexit, but what they were actually discussing was the final version of the Economic Development Plan. Read More Dartmoor ponies may have to be rounded up and shot because of Brexit, say worried volunteers
Cllr Tim Golder, Portfolio Holder for Economy, added: “This lays the foundation for the council’s business ventures to create well paid jobs. The Economic Development Plan is a strong step forward for this council to be business friendly.”
The five year plan sets out how the council will continue to directly support local businesses, broaden opportunities for residents and spur inclusive economic growth across the district.
The vision for the Teignbridge economy is to attract a diverse range of well-paid and highly skilled jobs for our residents and workers, to be an attractive place to start and grow a business and to prosper within ecological limits and to enhance the circular economy.
The plans include free public Wi-Fi in town centres. Phase 1 would see Teignbridge intend to deliver the installation of a public Wi-Fi solution for Newton Abbot, Teignmouth and Dawlish town centres that would be a no-cost option for the council, where both the provider and the council can profit from the application.
If the public Wi-Fi in Newton Abbot, Teignmouth and Dawlish is successful in generating an income for the council, then they will seek to extend the project to Ashburton, Bovey Tracey, Buckfastleigh, Chudleigh and Moretonhampstead town centres. Read More Reports suggest Exeter's House of Fraser store will close
The report outlines that phase one would hope to be delivered in 2019, and then if it is successful in generating income, phase two would be delivered between 2021 and 2023.
The free Wi-Fi plan would be at no cost to the council and would be free for the public to use.
Other plans include seeking to facilitate a peripatetic town centre manager role for Ashburton, Bovey Tracey, Buckfastleigh, Chudleigh and Moretonhampstead town centres, seeking to establish ‘enterprise hubs’ offering small office units for micro businesses, to continue the regeneration of Newton Abbot town centre and explore projects in other Teignbridge towns, and to establish a ‘business incubator’ approach to letting out selected council retail property, by offering training, support and helping tenants to grow.
